text: Superantigens activate HIV-1 gene expression in monocytic cells .
Binding of superantigens to MHC class II molecules results in transduction of biochemical signals leading to cellular activation and gene expression .

We demonstrate that the staphylococcal superantigens <extra_id_0> toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> TSST-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) and <extra_id_0> staphylococcal enterotoxin A <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> SEA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) activate HIV-1-LTR - driven transcription of <extra_id_0> chloramphenicol acetyl transferase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in the human monocytic cell line THP-1 .

text: Induction of HIV-1-LTR - driven transcription in THP-1 cells by superantigens was associated with the induction of nuclear factor-kappa B DNA - binding activity .

Superantigens also increased viral protein secretion from the <extra_id_0> granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - pretreated chronically infected human monocytic cell line U1 .

Induction of HIV-1 gene expression in monocytic cells by superantigens occurred via <extra_id_0> tumor necrosis factor-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - dependent and - independent mechanisms .
Our results suggest that superantigens and other MHC class II ligands may activate HIV-1 gene expression in monocytes / macrophages .
